From: Jeff Clune <jclune@...>
Subject: Re: [neat] Evolving ANNs that are Both Modular and Regular: HyperNEAT+CCT
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=464818732; y=zhRzqFMmlq-miGmOkfHy8PKk_7i4L_5-SzEjVuit-YHXXjowtvEK
X-Yahoo-Profile: jeffreyclune


--Apple-Mail=_5C0E2ECC-3E40-4410-831E-AA771FF000CB
Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable
Content-Type: text/plain;
	charset=windows-1252

Hello Ken, 

Please see below. 

> Hi Jeff, first congrats on having this n=
ice, comprehensive study of modularity in HyperNEAT accepted at GECCO.  
> =

> This paper raises a number of interesting issues.  Among the most obviou=
s, the connection-cost technique (CCT) clearly yields a profound positive e=
ffect on modularity, which also helped solve the problems.  This result cer=
tainly gives weight to the value of the CCT.
> 
> 
Thank you. We are please=
d that, so far, every time we=92ve applied the CCT to a problem it has impr=
oved performance and modularity. We are increasingly confident that it is a=
 robust, effective technique, at least based on what we=92ve observed in th=
e last year. 

> Going back to our previous debate, on the issue of the int=
eraction with the Gaussian Seed (GS) (which had previously been shown to he=
lp the LEO with modularity), there are a lot of nuances to the implications=
 of this result.  First, the implications are slightly muddied by the fact =
that the results do not reproduce the same performance seen in my paper wit=
h Phillip Vebancsics on the LEO with the GS.  It would have been really int=
eresting to see both these methods compete in exactly the domain with exact=
ly the performance we originally reported.  However, given that the LEO-GS =
results here look a bit worse than ours, there could be some implementation=
 differences at play (as you note), but it makes it hard to be sure whether=
 the GS cannot be tweaked somehow more to look better. 
> 
Agreed. We tried=
 to make LEO-GS work by playing with its key parameter a bit, but it did no=
t help. Because it wasn=92t the main focus of the paper, we did not invest =
a ton of time into tweaking all possible parameters to see if something wou=
ld have elevated its performance. As we say in the paper, that may suggest =
that hand-creating the seed is a difficult enterprise to get right. Then ag=
ain, it could be that something about this specific implementation of the p=
roblem made tuning LEO-GS difficult. 

> But let's proceed with the assumpt=
ion that the GS simply doesn't perform as well in the setup attempted here =
regardless of implementation details, since that's still interesting to con=
sider and likely true.
> 
> That is, the results under this interpretation =
makes sense.  After all, the problem is modular and a pressure to maintain =
modularity through the CCT is helpful.  That seems reasonable.  The GS lose=
s its modularity, probably because there is some kind of deception in the s=
earch space that makes it appear early on that being less modular increases=
 fitness.  But CCT can't be "lost" so it keeps pushing in the direction we =
want.  The conclusion is pretty clear for this problem setup:  CCT is more =
effective.
> 
> But that raises an interesting question:  What if there is =
a problem whose best solution is not modular?  Then the CCT would presumabl=
y be a persistent liability.  Of course, realistically, modularity is proba=
bly useful in many problems so you could say perhaps that we don't really c=
are about 100% non-modular problems.  But the real subtlety comes in if the=
 problem is partly non-modular and partly modular.  How will the blunt forc=
e of a single CCT deal with the nuance of varying degrees of optimal modula=
rity in different parts of the solution?  It seems perhaps ill suited.  Tha=
t is a big concern given that we are interested in moving on to more comple=
x problems, which likely means problems with a lot of this very kind of nua=
nce.
> 
> 
I do agree that most challenging problems are modular, so I am n=
ot worried about doing worse on non-modular problems. That said, we tried t=
he CCT on a non-modular problem in the original paper =93The Evolutionary O=
rigins of Modularity=94 (http://goo.gl/2vzFv). Performance was not hurt by =
the CCT, but of course things could work differently on different, non-modu=
lar problems. My guess it that if connections are necessary, then their cos=
t will be justified by the performance improvement they bring, and thus non=
-modular networks can evolve. Of course, a consistent bias in the wrong dir=
ection could hurt search, especially when the extra connections do not pay =
for themselves in the short term (in diversity or performance), but we are =
finding empirically that the CCT tends to help in many different types of p=
roblems (including in papers not yet published). 

One benefit to the CCT t=
hat we have not discussed is that it is a parsimony pressure. In other word=
s, it encourages simplicity unless complexity is justified. In machine lear=
ning terminology, it is a regularization pressure. Thus, for the same reaso=
n that in NEAT you prefer to start simple and only get more complex if nece=
ssary, the CCT says =93try to make the simplest network you can, but if mor=
e connections buy you increased performance, that=92s fine.=94

Does that m=
ake you more convinced that the CCT might be a good bias in general to cons=
istently have during search, and not a "blunt instrument"?

As for problems=
 where some part of the space is non-modular, I think the same arguments ap=
ply. The CCT allows those extra connections if they earn their keep. 

A fi=
nal point to mention (which Joost just reminded me of in a side conversatio=
n), is that the CCT can be made to count much less than the performance pre=
ssure. We did just that in both the original paper and this paper via havin=
g the connection cost objective only factor into selection a fraction of th=
e time probabilistically. Thus, the connection cost pressure can be made to=
 be slight, allowing evolution to explore solutions with more connections f=
or many generations before they are ultimately culled by the infrequent pen=
alty of having them. 

> Yet the GS on its own doesn't really "solve" that =
issue either because the GS itself is still subject to deception (as you re=
sults show), so although in principle the GS can get you all the subtlety y=
ou need (unlike CCT), and thereby solve even such convoluted problems, it w=
ill likely top out at some kind of suboptimal configuration due to deceptio=
n.
> 
> Overall, my argument here is going in a familiar direction.  Here w=
e have a speculative hypothetical situation (desiring varying degrees of mo=
dularity in the same solution) in which perhaps no method is suited.  But t=
he reason for that is the usual culprit: the problems we are discussing (in=
cluding in this paper) are objectively driven.  I've argued consistently th=
at our ability to discover really interesting brain-like structures through=
 objectively-driven evolution will turn out limited.  If we are considering=
 discovering something radically complex with varying degrees of modularity=
 throughout it, then it is almost certain that it won't happen primarily th=
rough objectives.  That insight raises the question of which will be the be=
st tool then under non-objective conditions: GS or CCT.  I'd argue there th=
at the GS is more aligned with the non-objective spirit because it means we=
 can look at all the possibilities without bias:  in one branch of evolutio=
n we will see the less modular, and in another branch the more.  There is n=
o presupposition about which will be better or even that anything is object=
ively better at all.   
> 
I disagree. In your last sentence you slip into =
talking about novelty in brain structure (=93we can look at all the possibi=
lities without bias: in one branch we see the less modular, and in another =
branch the more=94). But of course Novelty Search is looking for novelty in=
 behavior space, and it is hard to generate new, complex behaviors. My inst=
incts are that it will be easier to generate more types of different, compl=
ex behaviors with modular brains than with non-modular brains, for the same=
 reasons modularity helps in engineering. If that=92s true, then a decrease=
d amount of diversity in brain modularity (i.e. only having modular brains)=
 may still yet lead to a dramatic increase in the amount of behavior divers=
ity generated. 

The same idea applies with regularization/parsimony: parsi=
monious solutions tend to generalize better to new situations, which is a n=
ice property to have when trying to produce new behaviors that head off int=
o new parts of the environment to do new things. 

For both of these reason=
s, my guess is that the CCT will improve performance in Novelty Search (and=
 other non-objective searches) as well as in objective-driven searches. But=
 whether your hypothesis or mine is right would be fascinating to test rigo=
rously! Some evidence is already presented in our paper: both treatments ha=
ve a diversity objective, and the CCT performs better than LEO-GS, although=
 of course a performance objective is present too. 

> 
> However, I will g=
ive you that the CCT's effect in your paper is really cool and in practice =
it may be worth adding to see what happens, even combined with novelty sear=
ch.  But my concern is still that it's a bit of a blunt instrument if you a=
re aiming to construct a kind of masterpiece with the precision and intrica=
cy of open heart surgery, which a non-objective search might aim to do.  Em=
pirical experiments over time will settle these issues and CCT should defin=
itely be on the table in the meantime as an important option.  Also, in pra=
ctical situations that are either objective or perhaps not necessarily obje=
ctive but nevertheless known to be highly modular, CCT is pretty clearly th=
e preferred choice based on your results.
> 
> 
Thanks. I agree that we=92l=
l learn more with more tests, but that at present the CCT does look like a =
promising thing to try on most problems, either due to modularity, parsimon=
y, or (most likely) both. 

> Finally, as a practical issue, I'm just curio=
us about the one combination you didn't report:  CCT starting with a GS.  T=
his combo still doesn't address the subtle issues discussed above, but in p=
ractice it's interesting and could be cool.  Maybe it would be even better =
than CCT alone at the problems in the paper?
> 
> 
That=92s an interesting =
idea. We did not try it, but if we have time we=92ll try to do so and let y=
ou (and the community) know what happens. 

Thanks again for the kind words=
 about our work and the ever-interesting discussion.

-Jeff


> Best,
> 
> =
ken
> 
> 
> 
> 
> 
> -combining with GS?/
> 
> 


--Apple-Mail=_5C0E2ECC-3E40-4410-831E-AA771FF000CB

Content-Type: text/html;
	charset=windows-1252

    <div id=3D"ygrp-text"=
><p>Hi Jeff, first congrats on having this nice, comprehensive study of mod=
ularity in HyperNEAT accepted at GECCO.  <br><br>This paper raises a n=
umber of interesting issues.  Among the most obvious, the connection-c=
ost technique (CCT) clearly yields a profound positive effect on modularity=
, which also helped solve the problems.  This result certainly gives w=
eight to the value of the CCT.<br><br></p></div></div></div></div></blockqu=
ote><div>Thank you. We are pleased that, so far, every time we=92ve applied=
 the CCT to a problem it has improved performance and modularity. We are in=
creasingly confident that it is a robust, effective technique, at least bas=
ed on what we=92ve observed in the last year. </div><div><br></div><bl=
ockquote type=3D"cite"><div style=3D"background-color: rgb(255, 255, 255); =
position: static; z-index: auto;"><div id=3D"ygrp-mlmsg" style=3D"position:=
relative;"><div id=3D"ygrp-msg" style=3D"z-index: 1;"><div id=3D"ygrp-text"=
><p>Going back to our previous debate, on the issue of the interaction with=
 the Gaussian Seed (GS) (which had previously been shown to help the LEO wi=
th modularity), there are a lot of nuances to the implications of this resu=
lt.  First, the implications are slightly muddied by the fact that the=
 results do not reproduce the same performance seen in my paper with Philli=
p Vebancsics on the LEO with the GS.  It would have been really intere=
sting to see both these methods compete in exactly the domain with exactly =
the performance we originally reported.  However, given that the LEO-G=
S results here look a bit worse than ours, there could be some implementati=
on differences at play (as you note), but it makes it hard to be sure wheth=
er the GS cannot be tweaked somehow more to look better.  </p></div></=
div></div></div></blockquote><div>Agreed. We tried to make LEO-GS work by p=
laying with its key parameter a bit, but it did not help. Because it wasn=
=92t the main focus of the paper, we did not invest a ton of time into twea=
king all possible parameters to see if something would have elevated its pe=
rformance. As we say in the paper, that may suggest that hand-creating the =
seed is a difficult enterprise to get right. Then again, it could be that s=
omething about this specific implementation of the problem made tuning LEO-=
GS difficult. </div><div><br></div><blockquote type=3D"cite"><div styl=
e=3D"background-color: rgb(255, 255, 255); position: static; z-index: auto;=
"><div id=3D"ygrp-mlmsg" style=3D"position:relative;"><div id=3D"ygrp-msg" =
style=3D"z-index: 1;"><div id=3D"ygrp-text"><p>But let's proceed with the a=
ssumption that the GS simply doesn't perform as well in the setup attempted=
 here regardless of implementation details, since that's still interesting =
to consider and likely true.<br><br>That is, the results under this interpr=
etation makes sense.  After all, the problem is modular and a pressure=
 to maintain modularity through the CCT is helpful.  That seems reason=
able.  The GS loses its modularity, probably because there is some kin=
d of deception in the search space that makes it appear early on that being=
 less modular increases fitness.  But CCT can't be "lost" so it keeps =
pushing in the direction we want.  The conclusion is pretty clear for =
this problem setup:  CCT is more effective.<br><br>But that raises an =
interesting question:  What if there is a problem whose best solution =
is not modular?  Then the CCT would presumably be a persistent liabili=
ty.  Of course, realistically, modularity is probably useful in many p=
roblems so you could say perhaps that we don't really care about 100% non-m=
odular problems.  But the real subtlety comes in if the problem is par=
tly non-modular and partly modular.  How will the blunt force of a sin=
gle CCT deal with the nuance of varying degrees of optimal modularity in di=
fferent parts of the solution?  It seems perhaps ill suited.  Tha=
t is a big concern given that we are interested in moving on to more comple=
x problems, which likely means problems with a lot of this very kind of nua=
nce.<br><br></p></div></div></div></div></blockquote><div>I do agree that m=
ost challenging problems are modular, so I am not worried about doing worse=
 on non-modular problems. That said, we tried the CCT on a non-modular prob=
lem in the original paper =93The Evolutionary Origins of Modularity=94 (<a =
href=3D"http://goo.gl/2vzFv">http://goo.gl/2vzFv</a>). Performance was not =
hurt by the CCT, but of course things could work differently on different, =
non-modular problems. My guess it that if connections are necessary, then t=
heir cost will be justified by the performance improvement they bring, and =
thus non-modular networks can evolve. Of course, a consistent bias in the w=
rong direction could hurt search, especially when the extra connections do =
not pay for themselves in the short term (in diversity or performance), but=
 we are finding empirically that the CCT tends to help in many different ty=
pes of problems (including in papers not yet published). </div><div><b=
r></div><div>One benefit to the CCT that we have not discussed is that it i=
s a parsimony pressure. In other words, it encourages simplicity unless com=
plexity is justified. In machine learning terminology, it is a regularizati=
on pressure. Thus, for the same reason that in NEAT you prefer to start sim=
ple and only get more complex if necessary, the CCT says =93try to make the=
 simplest network you can, but if more connections buy you increased perfor=
mance, that=92s fine.=94</div><div><br></div><div>Does that make you more c=
onvinced that the CCT might be a good bias in general to consistently have =
during search, and not a "blunt instrument"?</div><div><br></div><div>As fo=
r problems where some part of the space is non-modular, I think the same ar=
guments apply. The CCT allows those extra connections if they earn their ke=
ep. </div><div><br></div><div>A final point to mention (which Joost ju=
st reminded me of in a side conversation), is that the CCT can be made to c=
ount much less than the performance pressure. We did just that in both the =
original paper and this paper via having the connection cost objective only=
 factor into selection a fraction of the time probabilistically. Thus, the =
connection cost pressure can be made to be slight, allowing evolution to ex=
plore solutions with more connections for many generations before they are =
ultimately culled by the infrequent penalty of having them. </div><div=
><br></div><blockquote type=3D"cite"><div style=3D"background-color: rgb(25=
5, 255, 255); position: static; z-index: auto;"><div id=3D"ygrp-mlmsg" styl=
e=3D"position:relative;"><div id=3D"ygrp-msg" style=3D"z-index: 1;"><div id=
=3D"ygrp-text"><p>Yet the GS on its own doesn't really "solve" that issue e=
ither because the GS itself is still subject to deception (as you results s=
how), so although in principle the GS can get you all the subtlety you need=
 (unlike CCT), and thereby solve even such convoluted problems, it will lik=
ely top out at some kind of suboptimal configuration due to deception.<br><=
br>Overall, my argument here is going in a familiar direction.  Here w=
e have a speculative hypothetical situation (desiring varying degrees of mo=
dularity in the same solution) in which perhaps no method is suited.  =
But the reason for that is the usual culprit: the problems we are discussin=
g (including in this paper) are objectively driven.  I've argued consi=
stently that our ability to discover really interesting brain-like structur=
es through objectively-driven evolution will turn out limited.  If we =
are considering discovering something radically complex with varying degree=
s of modularity throughout it, then it is almost certain that it won't happ=
en primarily through objectives.  That insight raises the question of =
which will be the best tool then under non-objective conditions: GS or CCT.=
  I'd argue there that the GS is more aligned with the non-objective s=
pirit because it means we can look at all the possibilities without bias:&n=
bsp; in one branch of evolution we will see the less modular, and in anothe=
r branch the more.  There is no presupposition about which will be bet=
ter or even that anything is objectively better at all.   <br></p=
></div></div></div></div></blockquote><div>I disagree. In your last sentenc=
e you slip into talking about novelty in brain structure (=93we can look at=
 all the possibilities without bias: in one branch we see the less modular,=
 and in another branch the more=94). But of course Novelty Search is lookin=
g for novelty in <i>behavior space</i>, and it is hard to generate new, com=
plex behaviors. My instincts are that it will be easier to generate more ty=
pes of different, complex behaviors with modular brains than with non-modul=
ar brains, for the same reasons modularity helps in engineering. If that=92=
s true, then a decreased amount of diversity in brain modularity (i.e. only=
 having modular brains) may still yet lead to a dramatic increase in the am=
ount of behavior diversity generated. </div><div><br></div><div>The sa=
me idea applies with regularization/parsimony: parsimonious solutions tend =
to generalize better to new situations, which is a nice property to have wh=
en trying to produce new behaviors that head off into new parts of the envi=
ronment to do new things. </div><div><br></div><div>For both of these =
reasons, my guess is that the CCT will improve performance in Novelty Searc=
h (and other non-objective searches) as well as in objective-driven searche=
s. But whether your hypothesis or mine is right would be fascinating to tes=
t rigorously! Some evidence is already presented in our paper: both treatme=
nts have a diversity objective, and the CCT performs better than LEO-GS, al=
though of course a performance objective is present too. </div><br><bl=
ockquote type=3D"cite"><div style=3D"background-color: rgb(255, 255, 255); =
position: static; z-index: auto;"><div id=3D"ygrp-mlmsg" style=3D"position:=
relative;"><div id=3D"ygrp-msg" style=3D"z-index: 1;"><div id=3D"ygrp-text"=
><p><br>However, I will give you that the CCT's effect in your paper is rea=
lly cool and in practice it may be worth adding to see what happens, even c=
ombined with novelty search.  But my concern is still that it's a bit =
of a blunt instrument if you are aiming to construct a kind of masterpiece =
with the precision and intricacy of open heart surgery, which a non-objecti=
ve search might aim to do.  Empirical experiments over time will settl=
e these issues and CCT should definitely be on the table in the meantime as=
 an important option.  Also, in practical situations that are either o=
bjective or perhaps not necessarily objective but nevertheless known to be =
highly modular, CCT is pretty clearly the preferred choice based on your re=
sults.<br><br></p></div></div></div></div></blockquote><div>Thanks. I agree=
 that we=92ll learn more with more tests, but that at present the CCT does =
look like a promising thing to try on most problems, either due to modulari=
ty, parsimony, or (most likely) both. </div><div><br></div><blockquote=
 type=3D"cite"><div style=3D"background-color: rgb(255, 255, 255); position=
: static; z-index: auto;"><div id=3D"ygrp-mlmsg" style=3D"position:relative=
;"><div id=3D"ygrp-msg" style=3D"z-index: 1;"><div id=3D"ygrp-text"><p>Fina=
lly, as a practical issue, I'm just curious about the one combination you d=
idn't report:  CCT starting with a GS.  This combo still doesn't =
address the subtle issues discussed above, but in practice it's interesting=
 and could be cool.  Maybe it would be even better than CCT alone at t=
he problems in the paper?<br><br></p></div></div></div></div></blockquote><=
div>That=92s an interesting idea. We did not try it, but if we have time we=
=92ll try to do so and let you (and the community) know what happens. =
</div><div><br></div><div>Thanks again for the kind words about our work an=
d the ever-interesting discussion.</div><div><br></div><div>-Jeff</div><div=
><br></div><br><blockquote type=3D"cite"><div style=3D"background-color: rg=
b(255, 255, 255); position: static; z-index: auto;"><div id=3D"ygrp-mlmsg" =
style=3D"position:relative;"><div id=3D"ygrp-msg" style=3D"z-index: 1;"><di=
v id=3D"ygrp-text"><p>Best,<br><br>ken<br><br><br><br><br><br>-combining wi=
th GS?/</p>

    </div>
     

    

</div>
